text:

As Article 50 is formally triggered, Sunderland is still torn over the EU issue. 
The city voted to break with Europe by 82,394 votes to 51,390 and provided the first mainland UK pro-Leave vote on referendum day. 
Roughly six out of 10 people in the area voted to go and it has become internationally synonymous with the vote. 
But those who put their cross in the box for Remain don’t show any signs of going down quietly. 
At the same time Britain’s permanent representative to the European Union, Tim Barrow, was handing over the formal notification of the UK’s departure to EU Council President Donald Tusk, a small protest assembled in the centre of Sunderland. 
Waving EU flags and chanting “Europeans are welcome here”, it was an image not usually associated with Wearside. 
Lina Dobreva, who came to Sunderland from Bulgaria to study psychology, was among the demonstrators who had been called on to rally by pressure group North East for Europe. Workers at Nissan's plant in Sunderland (Photo: Owen Humphreys/PA Wire) 
The 22-year-old fell in love with the area and stayed after she graduated. 
“There has been a lot of speculation in the media around Sunderland but it wasn’t the only place which voted to leave,” she said. 
“I think Sunderland is getting a bad image and it does not deserve it. 
“It’s been my home for four years and I love it.” Read More Letters reveal Nissan's wishlist - so is this how it was convinced to stay in the North East? 
The rights of EU citizens already living in the UK have become one of the most contentious parts of the debate already. 
Last month, the Commons voted to reject an amendment to the Brexit bill which would provided assurances for the nearly three million people effected. European Council President Donald Tusk (Photo: AP Photo/Virginia Mayo) 
It’s a level of uncertainty which has made Lina consider leaving her new home. 
“For me, uncertainty is the biggest issue right now. 
“We don’t know exactly what is going to happen, no one is sure exactly what Brexit will look like. 
“That worries me and I’m considering leaving the UK because of it. Read More 
“I can’t speak for everyone in my position but that’s how I feel. 
“I’m young and the world is full of opportunities. 
“There are opportunities in Sunderland too but now I’m facing a situation where I might not be able to easily return home if someone in my family suddenly fell ill, for example.” Britain's permanent representative to the European Union Tim Barrow, left, hand delivers British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit letter in notice of the UK's intention to leave the bloc under Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty to EU Council President Donald Tusk, in Brussels, Belgium, Wednesday, March 29, 2017 (Photo: REUTERS POOL) 
Niall Hodson, Liberal Democrat councillor for Millfield, says he isn’t surprised by the vocal Remain sentiment still present in the city. 
He said: “I think there’s a real sense of purpose now because there’s still a large set of questions which need answers. 
“We know we are leaving but there are huge unresolved issues around protecting EU citizens, protecting funding for universities and research, protecting investment and freedom of movement. 
“They all still need to be fought for. Read More 
“Our position is clear: we need a Brexit deal that protects these things. 
“In this city, 39% of people voted to Remain and their voices have been suppressed. 
“We’ve got EU citizens living in Sunderland and their rights need to be fought for. 
“This is a city which has benefited massively from the EU and we still have a lot to say.” Placards and flags are held by pro-EU protesters (Photo: PA) 
Sunderland is Britain’s top exporting city, with 60% going to the EU - thanks mostly to the giant Nissan car plant that churns out 500,000 cars a year. 
It employs around 7,000 people and tens of thousands more in the supply chain. 
Despite delighting the city by announcing they would stay after the vote, the long-term future of the site is far more uncertain. Read More How Brexit will affect house prices, pensions, and even playing the EuroMillions 
Colin Lawther, a Nissan senior vice president, said the firm would review the competitiveness of the Sunderland plant “as circumstances change”. 
Despite that, this certainly isn’t a city which has been totally overcome with “Bregret” and many of those who voted to Leave seem as sure of their decision as they were on June 23 2016. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
